title: Introduction to bridgr
text: Bridge models statistical tools designed address mismatch frequency economic indicators target variable, GDP. instance, GDP typically reported quarterly, many relevant indicators (e.g., industrial production, survey data) available monthly even daily. Bridge models “bridge” gap converting high-frequency indicators form aligns target variable’s frequency. models widely used nowcasting short-term forecasting. particularly useful : Data target variable reported lag (e.g., GDP often released delay). High-frequency indicators provide early signals state economy. leveraging real-time data, bridge models can improve forecast accuracy provide timely insights.

title: Introduction to bridgr
text: Bridge models exploit relationship target variable, quarterly GDP (y_t), multiple high-frequency indicators (x_{t}^{()}), observed monthly even higher frequencies. primary challenge harmonize different frequencies preserving information embedded indicators.

title: Introduction to bridgr
text: align high-frequency indicators (x_{t}^{()}) target variable’s frequency (y_t), transformation aggregation process applied. Let K represent number higher-frequency periods within single lower-frequency period (e.g., K=3 monthly data aggregated quarter). aggregation step can represented : \bar{x}_{t}^{()} =  \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \omega (k) L^{k/K} x_{t}^{()} : lag operator defined L^{1/3} x_{t}^{()} = x_{t-1/3}^{()} x_{t}^{()}: value indicator period t. \bar{x}_{t}^{()}: aggregated indicator period t. \omega (k): weight assigned k-th period higher frequency data. many applications, \omega (k) simply average values higher frequency periods. Alternative aggregation techniques include taking last observation (e.g., last month quarter) applying weighted averages.

title: Introduction to bridgr
text: indicators aligned target frequency, bridge model typically specified linear regression: y_t = \beta_0 + \sum_{ } \sum_{p_i=0}^{P^{()}} \beta_{p_i} L^p \bar{x}_{t}^{()} + \varepsilon_t : P^{()}: lags include indicator . \beta_{p_i}: Coefficients capturing relationship indicators target variable. \varepsilon_t: error term. Bridge models also handle cases high-frequency indicators fully observed time forecasting. cases, missing observations current period imputed forecast using time series models (e.g., ARIMA, ETS). allows predictions even recent observations missing. combination aggregation forecasting ensures bridge models versatile tools dealing incomplete data scenarios.

title: Introduction to bridgr
text: bridgr package simplifies construction estimation bridge models. vignette demonstrates use package quarterly GDP series (gdp) monthly economic indicator (baro).

title: Introduction to bridgr
text: example, two follwoing Swiss datasets used: gdp: Quarterly GDP data. baro: Monthly economic indicator data.  visualizing data,becomes obvious monthly economic indicator (baro) available higher frequency quarterly GDP data. Moreover, significant correlation.
code: # Load libraries library(bridgr) library(tsbox)  # Example data data("gdp")  # Quarterly GDP data data("baro") # Monthly economic indicator  gdp <- tsbox::ts_pc(gdp) # Calculate growth rate  # Visualize the data ts_ggplot(   ts_scale(ts_c(baro, gdp)),   title = "Quarterly gdp and monthly economic indicator",   subtitle = "Scaled to mean 0 and variance 1"   ) +   theme_tsbox()

title: Introduction to bridgr
text: calculating GDP growth rate, one observation less beginning GDP series. bridgefunction detects mismatched starting dates aligns earliest common date. model estimated using specified lags target indicator variables. h argument specifies number periods forecast lower frequency variable. bridge model returns dataset main model estimated well forecasted dataset indicator variables.
code: # Estimate the bridge model bridge_model <- bridge(   target = gdp,    indic = baro ,    indic_lags = 1,    target_lags=1,    h=2  ) #> The start dates of the target and indicator variables do not match. Aligning them to 2004-04-01 #> Dependent variable: gdp | Frequency: quarter | Estimation sample: 2004-04-01 - 2022-10-01 | Forecast horizon: 2 quarter(s) # Inspect the datasets tail(bridge_model$estimation_set) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   time        baro baro_lag1   gdp #>   <date>     <dbl>     <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 2021-07-01 112.      125.  2.34  #> 2 2021-10-01 104.      112.  0.411 #> 3 2022-01-01  97.4     104.  0.105 #> 4 2022-04-01  94.3      97.4 1.03  #> 5 2022-07-01  90.0      94.3 0.255 #> 6 2022-10-01  90.7      90.0 0.102 head(bridge_model$forecast_set) #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   time        baro baro_lag1 #>   <date>     <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 2023-01-01  97.4      90.7 #> 2 2023-04-01  99.8      97.4

title: Introduction to bridgr
code: # Forecasting using the bridge model fcst <- forecast(bridge_model)  forecast <- data.frame(   "time" = fcst$forecast_set$time,   "forecast" = as.numeric(fcst$mean) )  # Visualize the forecast ts_ggplot(   ts_span(ts_tbl(ts_c(gdp, forecast)), start = 2017),   title = "Forecasted GDP",   subtitle = "Bridge model forecast" ) +   theme_tsbox()

title: Introduction to bridgr
code: # Summarize the information in the bridge model summary(bridge_model) #> Bridge model summary #> ----------------------------------- #> Main model: #> ----------------------------------- #> Series:  gdp  #> Regression with ARIMA(1,0,0) errors  #>  #> Coefficients: #>          ar1  intercept    baro  baro_lag1 #>       0.2426    -6.4929  0.1615    -0.0917 #> s.e.  0.1213     1.3430  0.0125     0.0121 #>  #> sigma^2 = 0.5625:  log likelihood = -81.69 #> AIC=173.38   AICc=174.26   BIC=184.9 #> ----------------------------------- #> Single indicator models: #> ----------------------------------- #> Series:  baro  #> ARIMA(1,0,2) with non-zero mean  #>  #> Coefficients: #>          ar1     ma1     ma2      mean #>       0.6688  0.5305  0.3316  100.8580 #> s.e.  0.0653  0.0799  0.0753    1.5774 #>  #> sigma^2 = 18.46:  log likelihood = -646.14 #> AIC=1302.28   AICc=1302.55   BIC=1319.36 #> Aggregation to low frequency: #> Using mean over values in corresponding periods. #> -----------------------------------

what: Bridging Data Frequencies for Timely Economic Forecasts
title: Bridging Data Frequencies for Timely Economic Forecasts
text: bridgr designed simplify implementation evaluation bridge models, useful nowcasting (predicting present near-term) forecasting macroeconomic variables like GDP. Bridge models statistical tools link high-frequency indicators (e.g., monthly industrial production) low-frequency target variables (e.g., quarterly GDP) forecasting aggregating indicators match target’s frequency. enable timely predictions official release low-frequency data, making essential policymakers need early insights decision-making.

title: Bridging Data Frequencies for Timely Economic Forecasts
text: CRAN: can install development version bridgr like :

title: Bridging Data Frequencies for Timely Economic Forecasts
text: basic example:
code: library(bridgr)  gdp <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_pc(bridgr::gdp))  bridge_model <- bridge(   target = gdp,    indic = baro,    indic_predict = "auto.arima",    indic_lags = 2,    target_lags=1,    h=2 ) #> The start dates of the target and indicator variables do not match. Aligning them to 2004-04-01 #> Dependent variable: gdp | Frequency: quarter | Estimation sample: 2004-04-01 - 2022-10-01 | Forecast horizon: 2 quarter(s)  forecast(bridge_model) #>    Point Forecast      Lo 80    Hi 80      Lo 95    Hi 95 #> 74      0.8313868 -0.1302710 1.793045 -0.6393418 2.302115 #> 75      0.5363317 -0.4397745 1.512438 -0.9564939 2.029157  summary(bridge_model) #> Bridge model summary #> ----------------------------------- #> Main model: #> ----------------------------------- #> Series:  gdp  #> Regression with ARIMA(1,0,0) errors  #>  #> Coefficients: #>          ar1  intercept    baro  baro_lag1  baro_lag2 #>       0.1740    -7.4164  0.1574    -0.0957     0.0172 #> s.e.  0.1312     1.4152  0.0126     0.0125     0.0127 #>  #> sigma^2 = 0.5631:  log likelihood = -80.04 #> AIC=172.09   AICc=173.36   BIC=185.83 #> ----------------------------------- #> Single indicator models: #> ----------------------------------- #> Series:  baro  #> ARIMA(1,0,2) with non-zero mean  #>  #> Coefficients: #>          ar1     ma1     ma2      mean #>       0.6688  0.5305  0.3316  100.8580 #> s.e.  0.0653  0.0799  0.0753    1.5774 #>  #> sigma^2 = 18.46:  log likelihood = -646.14 #> AIC=1302.28   AICc=1302.55   BIC=1319.36 #> Aggregation to low frequency: #> Using mean over values in corresponding periods. #> -----------------------------------

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: function estimates bridge model, aligning high-frequency indicator variables lower-frequency target variable perform nowcasting forecasting. bridge model leverages time series alignment, lag structures, forecasting methods provide comprehensive tool time series analysis.

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
code: bridge(   target,   indic,   indic_predict = NULL,   indic_aggregators = NULL,   indic_lags = 0,   target_lags = 0,   h = 1,   frequency_conversions = c(dpw = 5, wpm = 4, mpq = 3, qpy = 4),   ... )

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: target time series data frame representing target variable (dependent variable). Must format compatible tsbox package (see tsbox::ts_boxable()). indic time series, list time series, data frame containing indicator variables (independent variables). Must format compatible tsbox package (see tsbox::ts_boxable()). indic_predict character string vector specifying forecasting method(s) indicator variables. Supported methods include "mean", "last", "auto.arima", "ets". Defaults "auto.arima". indic_aggregators character string vector specifying aggregation method(s) aligning indicator variables target variable. Supported methods include "mean", "last", "expalmon", "sum" o custom vector weights length frequency ratio. Defaults "mean". indic_lags integer vector integers specifying number lags include indicator variables. Defaults 0 (lags). target_lags integer specifying number lags include target variable. Defaults 0 (lags). h integer specifying forecast horizon terms target variable's frequency. Defaults 1 (next period). frequency_conversions named vector specifying conversion factors different time frequencies. Defaults c("dpw" = 5, "wpm" = 4, "mpq" = 3, "qpy" = 4) days per week, weeks per month, months per quarter, quarters per year, respectively. ... Additional arguments future extension, used moment.

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: object class "bridge" containing: target: standardized target variable. indic: standardized indicator variables. indic_predict: prediction methods applied indicators. indic_aggregators: aggregation methods used indicators. estimation_set: data frame containing aligned processed time series used estimate bridge model. set includes target variable indicator variables transformed match target variable's frequency alignment. forecast_set: data frame containing aligned processed time series used forecasting. includes forecasts indicator variables inputs h-step ahead prediction target variable. model: fitted bridge model object target variable. indic_models: list models used forecast indicator variables. element list corresponds forecasting method (e.g., auto.arima ets) applied individual indicator variable. Additional components: Internal parameters, summary statistics, alignment metadata.

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: bridge model aligns time series different frequencies slicing aggregating indicator variables match target variable's frequency. uses predefined rules frequency conversion alignment. function checks mismatches start dates aligns variables necessary.

what: Forecasting methods for the indicator variables
title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: auto.arima: Automatically selects best ARIMA (AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average) model given time series based information criteria (e.g., AIC, AICc, BIC). method identifies orders AR (p), differencing (d), MA (q) components estimates model parameters. particularly suitable time series seasonality, trends, non-stationary patterns. ets: Fits exponential smoothing state-space model data. ETS framework automatically includes Error (additive multiplicative), Trend (none, additive, damped), Seasonal (none, additive, multiplicative) components. method effective capturing underlying patterns data level, trend, seasonality, making suitable time series features.

what: Aggregation methods for the indicator variables
title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: mean: Calculates mean indicator variable values within target period. last: Takes last value indicator variable within target period. expalmon: Estimates nonlinear exponential almon lag polynomial weighting indicator. sum: Calculates sum indicator variable values within target period. Custom weights: Allows user specify custom weights aggregating indicator variables.

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: Baffigi, ., Golinelli, R., & Parigi, G. (2004). Bridge models forecast euro area GDP. International Journal Forecasting, 20(3), 447–460. doi:10.1016/S0169-2070(03)00067-0 Burri, M. (2023). daily lead texts help nowcasting GDP growth? IRENE Working Papers 23-02. https://www5.unine.ch/RePEc/ftp/irn/pdfs/WP23-02.pdf Schumacher, C. (2016). comparison MIDAS bridge equations. International Journal Forecasting, 32(2), 257–270. doi:10.1016/j.ijforecast.2015.07.004

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
text: Marc Burri

title: Estimate a Bridge Model — bridge
code: library(bridgr)  # Example usage target_series <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_tbl(data.frame(   time = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2022-12-01"), by = "quarter"),   value = rnorm(12) )))  indic_series <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_tbl(data.frame(   time = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2023-01-01"), by = "month"),   value = rnorm(37) )))  bridge_model <- suppressMessages(bridge(   target = target_series,   indic = indic_series,   indic_predict = "mean",   indic_aggregators = "mean",   indic_lags = 2,   target_lags = 1,   h = 1 ))

title: Forecasting from a bridge object — forecast.bridge
code: # S3 method for class 'bridge' forecast(object, xreg = NULL, ...)

title: Forecasting from a bridge object — forecast.bridge
text: object bridge object obtained bridge(). xreg tsbox::ts_boxable() series external regressors. supplied user, forecast set calculated bridge() used. useful made scenarios. ... Additional arguments passed forecast function. Ignored moment.

title: Forecasting from a bridge object — forecast.bridge
text: object class "forecast". object class "forecast" list usually containing least following elements: model list containing information fitted model method name forecasting method character string mean Point forecasts time series lower Lower limits prediction intervals upper Upper limits prediction intervals level confidence values associated prediction intervals x original time series (either object time series used create model stored object). residuals Residuals fitted model. models additive errors, residuals x minus fitted values. fitted Fitted values (one-step forecasts) forecast_set forecast set forecasted indicator variables used calculate forecast target variable.

title: Forecasting from a bridge object — forecast.bridge
code: library(bridgr)  # Example usage target_series <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_tbl(data.frame(   time = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2022-12-01"), by = "quarter"),   value = rnorm(12) )))  indic_series <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_tbl(data.frame(   time = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2023-01-01"), by = "month"),   value = rnorm(37) )))  bridge_model <- suppressMessages(bridge(   target = target_series,   indic = indic_series,   indic_predict = "mean",   indic_aggregators = "mean",   indic_lags = 2,   target_lags = 1,   h = 1 ))  # Forecasting using the bridge model fcst <- forecast(bridge_model)

title: Swiss Economic Indicators — gdp
text: collection datasets containing economic indicators Switzerland.

title: Swiss Economic Indicators — gdp
text: baro: KOF barometer, monthly business cycle indicator. fcurve: F-curve, daily business cycle indicator. gdp: Quarterly GDP data (real, seasonally adjusted). wea: Weekly Economic Activity (WEA) indicator.

title: Swiss Economic Indicators — gdp
text: baro: Source: KOF Swiss Economic Institute Timeframe: January 2004 - December 2022 Frequency: Monthly Format: tibble monthly observations 2 variables: time: Date, month year observation. values: Numeric, value KOF barometer. fcurve: Source: Burri Kaufmann GitHub Timeframe: January 2004 - December 2022 Frequency: Daily Format: tibble daily observations 2 variables: time: Date, date observation. values: Numeric, value F-curve (inverted compatibility). gdp: Source: SECO Timeframe: January 2004 - December 2022 Frequency: Quarterly Format: tibble quarterly observations 2 variables: time: Date, quarter year observation. values: Numeric, real GDP (seasonally adjusted). wea: Source: SECO WEA Indicator Timeframe: January 2005 - December 2022 Frequency: Weekly Format: tibble weekly observations 2 variables: time: Date, week year observation. values: Numeric, value WEA.

title: Swiss Economic Indicators — gdp
code: # Load and plot `baro` data(baro) library(tsbox) suppressMessages(ts_plot(baro))

title: Summarize a bridge object — summary.bridge

title: Summarize a bridge object — summary.bridge
code: library(bridgr)  # Example usage target_series <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_tbl(data.frame(   time = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2022-12-01"), by = "quarter"),   value = rnorm(12) )))  indic_series <- suppressMessages(tsbox::ts_tbl(data.frame(   time = seq(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2023-01-01"), by = "month"),   value = rnorm(37) )))  bridge_model <- suppressMessages(bridge(   target = target_series,   indic = indic_series,   indic_predict = "mean",   indic_aggregators = "mean",   indic_lags = 2,   target_lags = 1,   h = 1 ))  # Summarize the information in the bridge model summary(bridge_model) #> Bridge model summary #> ----------------------------------- #> Main model: #> ----------------------------------- #> Series:  target_series  #> Regression with ARIMA(1,0,0) errors  #>  #> Coefficients: #>          ar1  intercept  indic_series  indic_series_lag1  indic_series_lag2 #>       0.5385    -0.5236        0.4651             0.1728            -0.1010 #> s.e.  0.4675     0.3916        0.3917             0.4238             0.4891 #>  #> sigma^2 = 0.572:  log likelihood = -8.1 #> AIC=28.2   AICc=56.2   BIC=30.02 #> ----------------------------------- #> Single indicator models: #> ----------------------------------- #> Series:  indic_series  #> Writing forward the mean over values in last low frequency period. #> Aggregation to low frequency: #> Using mean over values in corresponding periods. #> -----------------------------------

title: bridgr 0.1.0.9000
text: Added gdp,baro, wea fcurve datasets. Added bridge(), forecast() summary() functions. Supports target variables monthly, quarterly yearly frequency, indicator variables daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly yearly frequency. Supports auto.arima, ets methods indicator variable forecasting. Supports aggregation indicator variables match target’s frequency using custom weighting functions, exponential Almon polynomials methods.
